title: Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure
subtitle: Section 3: Cybercrime Underground Focus on C2 infrastructure profiling
learning_objectives: Summarize why Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure matters for open-source intelligence investigations and how it guides decision-making.
Apply C2 infrastructure profiling and bulletproof hosting to a scripted incident and document the workflow.
Evaluate telemetry, communication, and automation opportunities discovered while rehearsing Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure.
Coach peers through the lesson structure and record measurable improvements across the team.

post_assessment.question: How does C2 infrastructure profiling strengthen the Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure workflow?
options: It distracts intelligence analysts from open-source intelligence investigations priorities by focusing on unrelated administrative work.
It guides intelligence analysts to gather evidence, compare telemetry, and communicate findings tied to open-source intelligence investigations.
It encourages teams to skip documentation and rely on ad-hoc conversations during crises.
It replaces the need for collaboration with external partners and legal advisors.
post_assessment.explanation: C2 infrastructure profiling provides structure for capturing observations, testing hypotheses, and looping in stakeholders so the Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure process consistently improves.

content.text:
### Section 3: Cybercrime Underground – Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure

Intelligence analysts rely on **Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure** to express why this portion of the curriculum matters. The lesson connects strategy and day-to-day execution so the team can describe what good looks like when safeguarding open-source intelligence investigations.

Remember from the planning notes: Infrastructure-based threat tracking

C2 infrastructure profiling keeps intelligence analysts grounded in repeatable practice. Within open-source intelligence investigations, this element clarifies how to brief peers, review telemetry, and translate the section 3: cybercrime underground commitments into measurable action. Kickoff workshops should document baseline data, escalation triggers, and links to automation backlogs so the entire unit understands how c2 infrastructure profiling supports resilience and recovery.

bulletproof hosting keeps intelligence analysts grounded in repeatable practice. Within open-source intelligence investigations, this element clarifies how to brief peers, review telemetry, and translate the section 3: cybercrime underground commitments into measurable action. Kickoff workshops should document baseline data, escalation triggers, and links to automation backlogs so the entire unit understands how bulletproof hosting supports resilience and recovery.

domain/IP pivoting keeps intelligence analysts grounded in repeatable practice. Within open-source intelligence investigations, this element clarifies how to brief peers, review telemetry, and translate the section 3: cybercrime underground commitments into measurable action. Kickoff workshops should document baseline data, escalation triggers, and links to automation backlogs so the entire unit understands how domain/ip pivoting supports resilience and recovery.

shared infrastructure keeps intelligence analysts grounded in repeatable practice. Within open-source intelligence investigations, this element clarifies how to brief peers, review telemetry, and translate the section 3: cybercrime underground commitments into measurable action. Kickoff workshops should document baseline data, escalation triggers, and links to automation backlogs so the entire unit understands how shared infrastructure supports resilience and recovery.

Close the section by capturing success metrics, owner assignments, and retrospectives that prove the investigating cybercrime infrastructure habits are embedded across the program.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nlqXEZ4YvhM — Trace Labs investigators demonstrate cryptocurrency and underground OSINT techniques similar to the tradecraft you will practice here.

### Section 3: Cybercrime Underground – Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure

Intelligence analysts rely on **Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure** to express why this portion of the curriculum matters. The lesson connects strategy and day-to-day execution so the team can describe what good looks like when safeguarding open-source intelligence investigations.

Remember from the planning notes: Infrastructure-based threat tracking

Within open-source intelligence investigations, this element clarifies how to brief peers, review telemetry, and translate the section 3: cybercrime underground commitments into measurable action. Close the section by capturing success metrics, owner assignments, and retrospectives that prove the investigating cybercrime infrastructure habits are embedded across the program.

## Hands-on Simulation for Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure

Set up a sandbox aligned with section 3: cybercrime underground commitments. The goal is to narrate every investigative move so intelligence analysts can replay the workflow with new data sets.

1. Draft a playbook segment around **C2 infrastructure profiling**. Identify required tooling, the evidence collected, and the triage decisions the team must make. Capture command output, dashboards, and analyst notes.

2. Draft a playbook segment around **bulletproof hosting**. Identify required tooling, the evidence collected, and the triage decisions the team must make. Capture command output, dashboards, and analyst notes.

3. Draft a playbook segment around **domain/IP pivoting**. Identify required tooling, the evidence collected, and the triage decisions the team must make. Capture command output, dashboards, and analyst notes.

4. Draft a playbook segment around **shared infrastructure**. Identify required tooling, the evidence collected, and the triage decisions the team must make. Capture command output, dashboards, and analyst notes.

5. Draft a playbook segment around **passive DNS**. Identify required tooling, the evidence collected, and the triage decisions the team must make. Capture command output, dashboards, and analyst notes.

6. Draft a playbook segment around **certificate analysis**. Identify required tooling, the evidence collected, and the triage decisions the team must make. Capture command output, dashboards, and analyst notes.

After the walkthrough, schedule a peer review. Each analyst explains what worked, what required escalation, and how to automate repetitive steps without losing investigative rigor.

Finish by updating the runbook, linking recorded sessions, and tagging knowledge base articles so future rotations learn from the exercise.

## Case Study: Applying Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure

A regional team experienced a high-pressure incident that exposed gaps in open-source intelligence investigations. Intelligence analysts regrouped and replayed the timeline using the lesson structure from Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure.

They cataloged the signals they missed, the collaboration friction they encountered, and the stakeholders who needed clearer communication. By aligning remediation tasks to the lesson structure, they closed visibility gaps and launched new detection backlogs.

During the postmortem, the team recorded how executive updates, compliance obligations, and vendor coordination all tied back to the lesson pillars. This ensured future incidents would follow a confident, rehearsed pathway to containment.

Planning reminder: Infrastructure-based threat tracking

## Memory Architectures

### Mnemonic: ICI

Associate the acronym with the mission of this lesson. Visualize a war room where each station is labeled with these initials, reminding the crew how to defend open-source intelligence investigations under stress.

- I – C2 infrastructure profiling
- C – bulletproof hosting
- I – domain/IP pivoting

### Mnemonic: ICI

Use this alternate mnemonic to trigger rapid debriefs. Picture sticky notes, dashboards, and alerts all echoing these letters so the practice becomes muscle memory.

- I – Lessons Learned
- C – Resilience Testing
- I – Automation Backlog

Turn both memory tools into cue cards, whiteboard sketches, and spaced-repetition prompts so the team revisits them weekly.

## Quick Knowledge Check: Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure

Discuss these prompts with a teammate before attempting the formal post-assessment. Emphasize storytelling and decision rationale.

- How does **C2 infrastructure profiling** influence the triage path, and which warning signs should intelligence analysts flag immediately?

- How does **bulletproof hosting** influence the triage path, and which warning signs should intelligence analysts flag immediately?

- How does **domain/IP pivoting** influence the triage path, and which warning signs should intelligence analysts flag immediately?

Capture the answers in your runbook and update escalation thresholds so the lesson becomes part of daily stand-ups.

## Reflection Journal

- When did you last witness a breakdown in open-source intelligence investigations, and how would the Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure workflow change the outcome?
- Which allies outside your immediate team should be briefed on this lesson so intelligence analysts have faster support?
- What metric will you watch over the next two sprints to prove the lesson is embedded?

## Mindset Coach

This is an advanced journey. Celebrate each iteration where intelligence analysts narrate what they learned, how they collaborated, and which safeguards they reinforced.

Treat mistakes as signal. Document them, share the story, and adjust the playbook so confidence keeps growing while working through Investigating Cybercrime Infrastructure.

End every session by identifying one action you can automate, one teammate you can mentor, and one stakeholder update you can improve.
